item.title: Indonesia Grants Brazil, Turkey Visa-Free Entry in Tourism Push
item.description: Indonesia has extended visa-free entry to citizens of Brazil and Turkey, a rare privilege in the Southeast Asian nation aimed at boosting tourism and business ties.
item.dc:creator: Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: Visitors at Double Six beach in Seminyak, Bali. Nyimas Laula/Bloomberg

item.title: Lee Says Unsure South Korea Can Land US Trade Deal by Deadline
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung said it remains unclear if trade talks between Seoul and Washington can result in a deal before next week’s deadline to avert sweeping tariffs from President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae Myung Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: BOJ Board Member Says Rate Hikes to Resume After Temporary Pause
item.description: The Bank of Japan’s rate hike cycle will resume after “only” a temporary pause, Board Member Hajime Takata warned, keeping his hawkish tone even after President Donald Trump clouded the economic outlook by threatening to impose tariffs on Japanese goods even higher than those previously touted.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: Australia’s New Home Battery Plan And The Race for Net Zero
item.description: On this week’s Australia Podcast: Rebecca Jones speaks to Keira Wright about why Australia’s pushing for more people to install home batteries to store solar power.

media:content.media:description: A Solarpro employee holds a LG Electronics Inc. NeON R 370W solar panel ahead of installation on the rooftop of a residential property in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, May 17, 2021. Australia is the global leader in generating electricity from the sun. Some 27% of buildings had a solar system on their roof at the end of 2020, the highest proportion in the world, according to figures from BNEF.

item.title: China Services Activity Weakens to 9-Month Low in New Hurdle
item.description: China’s services activity slipped more than forecast to reach a nine-month low, a private survey showed, a worry for the economy as higher US tariffs threaten exports.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu, Yujing Liu

media:content.media:description: A sales person lifts a bamboo basket with steamed buns at a breakfast stall in Yuncheng, Shaanxi Province, China.

item.title: Bond Traders Eye High-Stakes US Jobs Report for Fed Rate Clues
item.description: Investors in the US Treasury market are zeroing in on a pivotal jobs report Thursday as they weigh the chances of the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates as soon as this month.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie, Michael Mackenzie

media:content.media:description: Commuters board a train at the 14th Street-Union Square subway station in New York. Photographer: Adam Gray/Bloomberg

item.title: Beijing Braces for US Trade Deals That Aim to Shut Out China
item.description: The trade truce between Washington and Beijing may be holding for now, but China is increasingly wary about what’s happening elsewhere: US efforts to forge deals that could isolate Chinese firms from global supply chains.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes and container ships at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai.

item.title: US June Jobs Report Set to Show Strain From Trump’s Policies
item.description: Forecasters anticipate a monthly report on US employment will show slower hiring and the highest unemployment rate since 2021 as the Trump administration’s trade and immigration policy shifts start to leave an imprint.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Boesler

item.title: Milei Is Tapping Argentina’s Permian in a Bid to Cement His Reforms
item.description: Oil exports are ramping up from the Vaca Muerta shale deposit in Patagonia after years of false starts. It’s a boom the libertarian president is counting on.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Gilbert

media:content.media:description: Argentina is emerging as home of the world’s next shale boom.

item.title: US-Vietnam Deal Risks China Reprisal, Bloomberg Economics Says
item.description: A new trade deal between the US and Vietnam risks provoking retaliatory steps from China as the accord includes a 40% tariff on goods deemed to be transshipped through the Southeast Asian country, according to Bloomberg Economics.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Emerging Asian Bonds Look Poised to Lure Back Overseas Funds
item.description: Asian bond markets may start to attract overseas investors once again thanks to resilient local currencies and the prospect of interest-rate cuts from regional central banks.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong

item.title: Australia’s Services Activity Improves, Costs Ease, S&P Says
item.description: Australia’s services sector activity accelerated in June and cost inflation softened, sending business confidence to its highest level in more than three years, according to S&P Global.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Diners at a cafe in Sydney. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

item.title: Powell Silence on His Future Complicates Trump Fed Chair Search
item.description: As President Donald Trump and his advisers begin weighing replacements for Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, they’re running into one significant complication: It’s not clear that Powell will leave the US central bank next year.
item.dc:creator: Saleha Mohsin, Joshua Green, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Bolivia Inflation Soars to 34-Year High Ahead of August Election
item.description: A crippling dollar shortage, fuel scarcity and mass unrest pushed Bolivia’s inflation rate to its fastest in more than three decades ahead of the nation’s general election.
item.dc:creator: Sergio Mendoza

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators gather on a main avenue during a drivers' union protest against fuel shortages in La Paz, Bolivia, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. The city center of Bolivia's political capital La Paz was paralyzed by a massive protest of thousands of public drivers demanding fuel amid shortages.

item.title: Japan’s Carmakers Absorbing Tariffs May Bolster Trump Position
item.description: Japanese carmakers have largely absorbed the cost of US President Donald Trump’s tariffs on auto imports, a move that may undermine the Asian nation’s negotiating power ahead of a July 9 deadline that will see duties rocket even higher.
item.dc:creator: Tsuyoshi Inajima, Phoebe Sedgman

media:content.media:description: Toyota Motor Corp. RAV4 compact crossover vehicles on display during an unveiling event in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, May 21, 2025. Toyota is scrapping the gas-powered version of its best-selling vehicle in the US as the Japanese carmaker doubles down on its push into hybrids.

item.title: Starmer Says Reeves Will Stay as UK Chancellor Despite Setbacks
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer said Rachel Reeves will stay on as Chancellor of the Exchequer, as he sought to draw a line under speculation about her future that sparked a bond selloff.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves and Prime Minister Keir Starmer Photographer: Jacob King/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Rio Tinto-Backed Aluminum Firm to Invest $1.1 Billion in Canada Project
item.description: Aluminerie Alouette, an aluminum maker that’s partially owned by Rio Tinto Plc, is planning to commit as much as C$1.5 billion ($1.1 billion) to modernizing its facilities in northern Quebec, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion

item.title: Australia Mulls Lowering Ultra-Long Bond Sales Amid Volatility
item.description: Australia’s debt manager is considering scaling back its issuance of ultra-long bonds as rising yields make funding more expensive.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Burgess

item.title: Influential Fed Supervision Official Takes Voluntary Resignation
item.description: Michael Gibson, director of the Federal Reserve’s supervision and regulation division, has accepted the agency’s voluntary resignation offer and plans to leave this month after more than three decades at the central bank, according to an internal email viewed by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Katanga Johnson

media:content.media:description: Michael Gibson

item.title: Argentina’s Peso Weakens as Seasonal Bonus Stokes Dollar Demand
item.description: Argentina’s peso extended its slide for a third session as seasonal demand for dollars picks up ahead of the South American winter holidays, while markets anticipate a dwindling supply of hard currency in the coming months.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Simauchi

media:content.media:description: Argentina lifted most currency controls in April after securing a new $20 billion program from the International Monetary Fund. Photographer: Tomas Cuesta/Bloomberg

item.title: Ethiopia Agrees Debt Restructuring Deal With Official Creditors
item.description: Ethiopia agreed a memorandum of understanding to restructure its loans with official creditors, formalizing a debt treatment plan offering relief for more than $3.5 billion.
item.dc:creator: Fasika Tadesse

media:content.media:description: Skyscraper office buildings on the city skyline in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Wednesday, Oct. 19, 2022. The International Monetary Fund forecasts economic expansion in Ethiopia will slow to 3.8% this year, with the nation also facing a severe shortage of foreign currency and soaring consumer prices. Photographer: Amanuel Sileshi/Bloomberg

item.title: What Will Be the Economic Fallout of Trump’s Immigration Crackdown?
item.description: In this episode of Trumponomics, we explore the potential for collateral damage and whether there will be an upside in the longer term for US-born workers.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: Workers install roofing on a home under construction in Vacaville, California, US, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. Mortgage rates in the US, declined for the fourth consecutive week, with the average 30-year fixed loan falling to 6.77%, the lowest level since early May and down from 6.81% the previous week, according to Freddie Mac.

item.title: Swiss-Norway Group and South America’s Mercosur Agree on Free-Trade Deal
item.description: The European Free Trade Association of Switzerland, Norway, Liechtenstein and Iceland concluded negotiations on a free-trade agreement with South America’s Mercosur countries in a push for more transatlantic commerce.
item.dc:creator: Levin Stamm, Bastian Benrath-Wright, Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Greenland Terminal in the port at Brevik, Norway.

item.title: Poland Delivers Rate-Cut Surprise With Inflation Set to Ease
item.description: Poland’s central bank unexpectedly cut interest rates after a one-month pause and said inflation is likely to ease within its target in the coming months, raising expectations that monetary easing is set to continue.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Shelves of household products on display at the Hala Mirowska market hall in downtown Warsaw, Poland, on Tuesday, April 2, 2024. Polish inflation fell to the central bank’s target for the first time in three years in March even as policymakers are expected to keep interest rates steady due to concerns over resurgent price growth later in 2024.

item.title: France Urgently Needs to Get a Grip on Finances, Auditor Warns
item.description: France must urgently take steps to rein in public finances or soon be forced into painful austerity, the country’s audit court said, highlighting the difficulties for a minority government already at risk of collapse over fiscal plans.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

item.title: S. Africa Inflation Expectations Drop to Near Four-Year Low
item.description: South African inflation expectations fell to an almost four-year low, providing policymakers with another reason to press ahead with their easing cycle.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Pretoria, South Africa. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: World’s Highest Real Rate Makes Case for Big Ghana Cut
item.description: Ghana’s real interest rate is the highest in the world, giving the central bank scope to deliver a sizable cut in borrowing costs later this month.
item.dc:creator: Ekow Dontoh, Moses Mozart Dzawu

item.description: Romania’s premier unveiled a package of tax hikes and wage freezes that aims to cut the budget deficit to below 6% of GDP next year and avoid a credit rating downgrade to junk.

item.title: IMF Sees Nigeria Fiscal Deficit Widening on Lower Oil Income
item.description: Nigerian economic reforms have improved investor sentiment but the nation’s finances are being hurt by lower oil prices that will widen its budget gap this year, said the International Monetary Fund.

item.title: US Private Payrolls Fall for First Time in Two Years in ADP Data
item.description: Employment at US companies fell in June for the first time in more than two years, reflecting a drop in services payrolls that may raise concerns about a more pronounced labor market slowdown.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette, Jarrell Dillard
